title: 115_s670
content: The Act titled "Over-the-Counter Hearing Aid Act of 2017" regulates over-the-counter hearing aids. The Over-the-Counter Hearing Aid Act of 2017 amends the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to regulate over-the-counter hearing aids for adults over 18 with mild to moderate hearing impairment. The Over-the-Counter Hearing Aid Act of 2017 regulates over-the-counter hearing aids for adults with mild to moderate hearing impairment. These aids allow users to customize them to their hearing needs, may use wireless technology, and can be obtained without a prescription. The Over-the-Counter Hearing Aid Act of 2017 mandates the creation of a category for over-the-counter hearing aids within 3 years of enactment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must propose and finalize regulations for this category within specified timeframes. The Over-the-Counter Hearing Aid Act of 2017 requires the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish regulations for over-the-counter hearing aids. The regulations must include safety and efficacy requirements, output limits, labeling guidelines, and conditions for sale. The Over-the-Counter Hearing Aid Act of 2017 allows the sale of hearing aids without the supervision of a licensed person, through various channels. The Secretary will determine if these over-the-counter hearing aids require premarket notification for safety and effectiveness. This Act preempts any conflicting state or local laws. The Over-the-Counter Hearing Aid Act of 2017 allows for the sale of hearing aids without the supervision of a licensed person, through various channels. Any laws, regulations, or requirements that restrict or interfere with the distribution of over-the-counter hearing aids must align with the regulations under this Act. This Act preempts conflicting state or local laws. The Secretary will update and finalize guidance on hearing aid devices and personal sound amplification products to clarify which products meet the definition of a device or a personal sound amplification product based on marketing claims or labeling material.
